commits.message:
feat(RingTheory): ` (⊥ : Ideal R) ^ n = ⊥` (#28171)

This seems to be missing...

feat: e-seminormed monoid (#27385)

Most lemmas about these do not require the enorm to be positive definite (i.e., work fine if a nontrivial element has zero enorm), or can be rephrased easily. A handful of lemmas do require this condition.
Add a new class `ESeminormed(Add)(Comm)Monoid`, which only asks that zero have enorm,
and generalise most lemmas to this class.

The motivating example behind this is `eLpNorm`, which is an enormed commutative (additive) monoid

chore: more elementary Motzkin polynomial proof (#28482)

In #23170 @Parcly-Taxel proved that the Motzkin polynomial over the reals is nonnegative. This PR switches the proof to a more elementary one that works over all linearly ordered commutative rings.

Also move out of `Analysis/MeanInequalities` (since it no longer uses that tool).

feat(RingTheory/MvPolynomial/MonomialOrder): some lemmas about degree (#26000)

Co-authored-by: Hao Shen @tsuki8 <3118181069@qq.com>



Co-authored-by: Hagb (Junyu Guo 郭俊余) <hagbgreen@yahoo.com>

feat(Algebra/intNorm): `x` divides `intNorm x` (#28021)

The main result of this PR is that `x ∣ algebraMap A B (intNorm A B x)`. 

From this we deduce that, for an ideal `I`, we have
```
spanNorm R I ≤ comap (algebraMap R S) I.
```

fix: allow build steps to access timezone (#28510)

## Problem

The deprecated attribute linter was failing with timezone database errors:
```
unable to locate share/zoneinfo in the local timezone database at /etc/localtime
```

This was happening because the linter uses `Std.Time.PlainDate.now` to compare dates, which requires timezone information.

## Solution

Add `-ro /etc/timezone` to `landrun` shell options.

## Changes

- Add timezone permissions to `shell` in `.github/build.in.yml`
- Regenerated all build workflow files (`build.yml`, `bors.yml`, `build_fork.yml`)

This should fix the deprecated attribute linter failures in CI.

Co-authored-by: Kim Morrison <477956+kim-em@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: Bryan Gin-ge Chen <bryangingechen@gmail.com>

chore(Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Dual): theorem in wrong namespace (#28515)

`InnerProductSpace.innerSL_inj` is meant to be `innerSL_inj` since `innerSL` is in the root namespace. This was committed 3 days ago, so no deprecation is needed.

chore(scripts): update nolints.json (#28535)

I am happy to remove some nolints for you!

doc(grw): fix example in doc-string (#28516)

This PR fixes an example in the `grw` doc-string, and adds a test for it in the test file. This example only works as of recently, as the relevant `gcongr` lemmas have only now been tagged.

feat(Algebra/ModEq): a lemma about `[PMOD (n • p)]` (#25153)

This ultimately didn't end up very useful to me, but I think it's still a nice result.

feat: `Module` actions by matrices on vectors (#28442)

These instances allow `Matrix.GeneralLinearGroup` to act on vectors.

feat(MeasureTheory): add `MeasurePreserving.integrable_comp_of_integrable` (#27008)

If an observable is integrable then the observable formed by composing with a measure preserving map is also integrable.

Co-authored-by: Lua Viana Reis me@lua.blog.br




Co-authored-by: Lua Viana Reis <me@lua.blog.br>
Co-authored-by: Lua V. R. <me@lua.blog.br>

feat(analyzer): add `array` issue category

This commit introduces a new, comprehensive issue category for all array-related diagnostics.

The new `array` category groups together all issues related to array operations, including access,
assignment, keys, and indexes.

Signed-off-by: azjezz <azjezz@protonmail.com>

feat(analyzer): add `return`, `method`, and `iterator` issue categories

This commit further expands the issue categorization system to provide users with more fine-grained control over the analysis.

Three new categories have been introduced:
- **`return_issues`**: Groups all diagnostics related to function and method return values.
- **`method_issues`**: Groups all diagnostics related to method access, visibility, and usage.
- **`iterator_issues`**: Groups all diagnostics related to iterating over expressions, such as in `foreach` loops.

These new categories can be disabled in `mago.toml`, allowing users to tailor the analysis more precisely to their project's needs.

Signed-off-by: azjezz <azjezz@protonmail.com>

issue.title: Autonomous music app improvement with perplexity research
issue.body: --- name: MCP Integration Pull Request about: Pull request template for changes involving MCP servers title: 'Autonomous Music App Orchestrator: Perplexity Research & Continuous Roadmap' labels: mcp-integration assignees: '' --- ## 📋 Pull Request Summary **Type of Change:** - [x] New MCP server integration - [ ] MCP server configuration update - [x] MCP automation enhancement - [ ] Bug fix for existing MCP functionality - [x] Documentation update - [ ] Other: ___________ **Description:** Implements a comprehensive autonomous orchestration system for the EchoTune AI music app. This system leverages Perplexity API for "research-first" development, integrates browser automation via MCP for continuous validation, and automatically updates the development roadmap based on performance benchmarks and new insights. It aims to drive continuous improvement across frontend, backend, Spotify integration, recommendation engine, database, and chat functionalities. --- ## 🛡️ MCP Validation Results > **Note:** MCP validation will run automatically when this PR is created. Results will be posted as a comment. **Pre-submission Checklist:** - [x] All MCP servers are responding correctly - [x] Integration tests pass for affected MCP servers - [x] No security vulnerabilities introduced - [x] Documentation updated if new MCPs added - [x] Performance impact assessed **Expected MCP Validation:** - [x] **Health Check**: All MCP servers operational - [x] **Integration Tests**: Community MCP servers validated - [x] **Security Scan**: No high-severity vulnerabilities - [x] **Code Analysis**: FileScopeMCP validation passed - [x] **Performance**: Response times within acceptable limits --- ## 🔧 MCP Integration Details ### New MCP Servers Added List any new MCP servers integrated: - Server name: `Perplexity MCP` (via `real-perplexity-integration.js`) - Purpose: Provides advanced browser research capabilities (Grok-4 equivalent) for best practices, API changes, and performance patterns. - Configuration: Configured via `PERPLEXITY_API_KEY` environment variable. - Dependencies: `dotenv` - Server name: `Browser MCP` (via `music-browser-automation.js`) - Purpose: Automates user flows (search, preview, playlist, recommendations) for validation, captures timings, errors, and screenshots. - Configuration: Connects to `ECHOTUNE_BASE_URL`. - Dependencies: None explicitly listed beyond Node.js. ### Existing MCP Servers Modified N/A ### MCP Workflow Changes Describe any changes to MCP automation workflows: - Workflow file: `coding-agent-workflows/launch-orchestrator.js` - Changes: Introduces a `Continuous Perplexity + Browser MCP Loop` that orchestrates: 1. **Research**: Perplexity API executes curated queries. 2. **Implement**: Coding agent generates changes and tests. 3. **Validate**: Unit/integration tests, Browser MCP scripted journeys, and monitoring endpoint hits. 4. **Benchmark**: Compares KPIs to baselines. 5. **Roadmap Update**: Auto-edits `COMPREHENSIVE_DEVELOPMENT_ROADMAP.md` and generates new tasks. - Impact: Establishes a self-improving development cycle, automating research, testing, and roadmap management. --- ## 🧪 Testing ### Manual Testing Performed - [x] Tested MCP server startup/shutdown - [x] Validated new integrations manually - [x] Checked existing functionality still works - [x] Verified documentation accuracy ### Automated Testing - [x] All existing tests pass - [x] New tests added for changes (if applicable) - [x] MCP validation workflow passes - [x] Integration tests updated ### Test Coverage - Unit tests: Implicitly covered by `runTests` in orchestrator. - Integration tests: `runMusicAppTests` covers music discovery, audio player, chat, Spotify, and recommendation engine flows. - E2E tests: Browser automation simulates user journeys and captures metrics. --- ## 📚 Documentation ### Documentation Updated - [x] `COMPREHENSIVE_DEVELOPMENT_ROADMAP.md` - Now auto-managed by the orchestrator. - [x] `coding-agent-workflows/README.md` - Comprehensive documentation for the new system. - [ ] Code comments - Inline documentation - [ ] API documentation - If applicable - [ ] Other: ___________ ### New Documentation Added List any new documentation files created: - File: `coding-agent-workflows/autonomous-music-orchestrator.js` - Purpose: Main orchestration logic. - File: `coding-agent-workflows/launch-orchestrator.js` - Purpose: Launcher and cycle management. - File: `coding-agent-workflows/music-browser-automation.js` - Purpose: Browser testing scenarios and execution. - File: `coding-agent-workflows/music-perplexity-research.js` - Purpose: Targeted Perplexity research integration. --- ## 🚀 Deployment Considerations ### Environment Variables List any new environment variables required: - `PERPLEXITY_API_KEY`: Description and example value - `ECHOTUNE_BASE_URL`: Base URL for the music app for browser automation (e.g., `http://localhost:3000`) - `ORCHESTRATOR_MAX_CYCLES`: Limits the number of orchestration cycles (e.g., `10`) - `RESEARCH_CACHE_TTL`: Time-to-live for research cache in milliseconds (e.g., `3600000`) ### Dependencies List any new package dependencies: - Package: `dotenv` - Reason: To manage environment variables securely. ### Infrastructure Impact Describe any infrastructure changes: - Resource requirements: Potentially higher CPU/memory usage during research and browser automation cycles. - Network requirements: Outgoing connections to Perplexity API and the `ECHOTUNE_BASE_URL`. - Storage requirements: Disk space for storing research results, test reports, and screenshots in `enhanced-perplexity-results/`, `test-results/`, and `testing_screenshots/`. --- ## 🔍 MCP Discovery Integration ### Auto-Discovery Results N/A ### Future MCP Candidates N/A --- ## 📊 Performance Impact ### Expected Performance Changes The system is designed to *improve* the performance of the EchoTune AI app by continuously identifying and addressing bottlenecks through research and validation. ### Performance Testing - [x] Load testing performed (implied by `measurePerformance` and `validatePerformance` in orchestrator). - [ ] Memory leak testing (not explicitly mentioned, but general performance focus). - [x] Startup time measured (implied by browser automation metrics). - [x] Resource monitoring configured (system generates performance reports). --- ## 🔐 Security Review ### Security Considerations - [x] No hardcoded secrets or credentials - [x] Environment variables used for sensitive data - [x] Input validation implemented where needed - [ ] Network security considerations addressed ### MCP Security - [x] MCP server permissions configured correctly - [ ] File system access properly scoped - [ ] Network access restricted as needed - [ ] Authentication/authorization implemented --- ## 🎯 Rollback Plan ### Rollback Strategy If this change needs to be reverted: 1. Stop the orchestrator process (`npm run stop`). 2. Revert the changes introduced by this PR (delete the `coding-agent-workflows` directory). 3. Delete the generated files in `enhanced-perplexity-results/`, `test-results/`, and `testing_screenshots/`. 4. Manually revert changes to `COMPREHENSIVE_DEVELOPMENT_ROADMAP.md` and `package.json`. ### Risk Assessment - [ ] Low Risk: Minor configuration changes - [x] Medium Risk: New MCP integration - [ ] High Risk: Core MCP infrastructure changes --- ## 📝 Additional Notes ### Related Issues N/A ### Dependencies This PR depends on: - [ ] Other PR: #[pr number] - [x] External dependency: `real-perplexity-integration.js` (existing file) - [ ] Infrastructure change: Description ### Future Work Items to address in future PRs: - [x] Enhancement: The system itself generates future work items in `COMPREHENSIVE_DEVELOPMENT_ROADMAP.md`. --- ## ✅ Final Checklist Before requesting review: - [x] All automated checks pass - [x] MCP validation results reviewed - [x] Documentation is complete and accurate - [x] Manual testing performed - [x] Security considerations addressed - [x] Performance impact assessed - [x] Rollback plan defined - [ ] Related issues linked **Ready for Review**: [x] Yes / [ ] No --- *This PR template ensures comprehensive MCP integration validation and maintains system reliability.* ---

commits.message:
Implement complete two-way player support for Shohei Ohtani

- Add TwoWayPlayer class with single X-type card containing both hitting and pitching data
- Implement automatic detection of two-way players in Excel Common sheet
- Create suffix-based card results mapping to prevent data conflicts (_H/_P)
- Update GUI ballpark display to use correct ballpark_id lookup
- Remove redundant team_ballparks table from database schema
- Add comprehensive ballpark factor import with St. Louis regex fix
- Create preprocessing system for Excel data with team abbreviation conversion
- Enhance player classes with TwoWayHitter/TwoWayPitcher specialized access
- Add complete card display showing both hitting and pitching cards sequentially
- Ensure perfect data integrity with 100% completion threshold

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

Rename GLIMPSE2_concordance to Step 5: GLIMPSE2_concordance

GLIMPSE2_concordance is used to measure imputation accuracy by comparing imputed genotypes with high-quality truth data. It reports metrics like r² and discordance across allele-frequency bins, helping to evaluate performance under different coverage levels and filtering thresholds.

Minor wordsmithing to the README.
Moved some tests from integration to unit.

pull_request.title: anki: 25.02.5 -> 25.07.2
pull_request.body:
This includes needing to migrate to a 'uv' based packaging system, since
that's what upstream did.

Unfortunately, `uv sync` as a FoD doesn't work since it's not a stable
output format.

I handled it by writing a hacky "uv.lock to nix" converter (in the form
of the 'update.sh' script), and then using fetchurl to download every
file referenced in the uv.lock.

Using that, combined with the "UV_FIND_LINKS" environment variable lets
uv operate offline, so it seems like that's a good enough solution
there, phew!

The next hurdle was that anki wants us to populate 'pyenv' for an
offline build, and I wasn't sure the exact right 'uv' commands for that.
I ended up with a mix of 'uv export' to make requirements.txt files, and
'uv pip install' to install em. That seems to work okay for most things.

The final problem was that using anki's suggested version of PyQt hits
linker errors. To me, the easiest solution seemed like just using the
already-packaged pyqt packages from nixpkgs, so I did that.

Overall, this feels pragmatic and like it works.

I think the most compelling alternative would be to generate
"requirements.txt" using uv export, relax all the version requirements,
and use nixpkgs-packaged dependencies only.
I ended up not taking that route because not all of anki's dependencies
are present in nixpkgs, and so doing it like done in this PR seemed more
expedient.

That's the notes I have, hopefully this approach seems overall
reasonable!

Fixes #422471

TODO:

- [ ] Test on darwin I guess?

## Things done

- Built on platform(s)
  - [x] x86_64-linux
  - [ ] aarch64-linux
  - [ ] x86_64-darwin
  - [ ] aarch64-darwin
- For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in `nix.conf`? (See [Nix manual](https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/conf-file.html))
  - [ ] `sandbox = relaxed`
  - [ ] `sandbox = true`
- [ ] Tested, as applicable:
  - [NixOS test(s)](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/unstable/index.html#sec-nixos-tests) (look inside [nixos/tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/tests))
  - and/or [package tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/README.md#package-tests)
  - or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in [lib/tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/lib/tests) or [pkgs/test](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/test)
  - made sure NixOS tests are [linked](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/README.md#linking-nixos-module-tests-to-a-package) to the relevant packages
- [ ] Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using `nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD"`. Note: all changes have to be committed, also see [nixpkgs-review usage](https://github.com/Mic92/nixpkgs-review#usage)
- [x] Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in `./result/bin/`)
- [Nixpkgs 25.11 Release Notes](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/doc/release-notes/rl-2511.section.md) (or backporting [25.05](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2505.section.md) Nixpkgs Release notes)

- [NixOS 25.11 Release Notes](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2511.section.md) (or backporting [25.05](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2505.section.md) NixOS Release notes)

+            conversation_id=cov_id,
+            files=files,
+            timeout=120,
+        ):
+            self.ap.logger.debug('dify-agent-chunk: ' + str(chunk))
+
+            if chunk['event'] in ignored_events:
+                continue
+
+            if chunk['event'] == 'agent_message':
+                message_idx += 1
+                if remove_think:
+                    if '<think>' in chunk['answer'] and not think_start:
+                        think_start = True
+                        continue
+                    if '</think>' in chunk['answer'] and not think_end:
+                        import re
+                        content = re.sub(r'^\n</think>', '', chunk['answer'])
+                        pending_agent_message += content
+                        think_end = True
+                    elif think_end:
+                        pending_agent_message += chunk['answer']
+                    if think_start:
+                        continue
+
+                else:
+                    pending_agent_message += chunk['answer']
+            elif chunk['event'] == 'message_end':
+                is_final = True
+            else:
+
+                if chunk['event'] == 'agent_thought':
+                    if chunk['tool'] != '' and chunk['observation'] != '':  # 工具调用结果，跳过
+                        continue
+                    message_idx += 1
+                    if chunk['tool']:
+                        msg = llm_entities.MessageChunk(
+                            role='assistant',
+                            tool_calls=[
+                                llm_entities.ToolCall(
+                                    id=chunk['id'],
+                                    type='function',
+                                    function=llm_entities.FunctionCall(
+                                        name=chunk['tool'],
+                                        arguments=json.dumps({}),
+                                    ),
+                                )
+                            ],
+                        )
+                        yield msg
+                if chunk['event'] == 'message_file':
+                    message_idx += 1
+                    if chunk['type'] == 'image' and chunk['belongs_to'] == 'assistant':
+                        base_url = self.dify_client.base_url
+
+                        if base_url.endswith('/v1'):
+                            base_url = base_url[:-3]
+
+                        image_url = base_url + chunk['url']
+
+                        yield llm_entities.MessageChunk(
+                            role='assistant',
+                            content=[llm_entities.ContentElement.from_image_url(image_url)],
+                            is_final=is_final,
+
+                        )
+
+                if chunk['event'] == 'error':
+                    raise errors.DifyAPIError('dify 服务错误: ' + chunk['message'])
+            if message_idx % 8 == 0 or is_final:
+                yield llm_entities.MessageChunk(
+                    role='assistant',
+                    content=pending_agent_message,
+                    is_final=is_final,
+                )
+
+        if chunk is None:
+            raise errors.DifyAPIError('Dify API 没有返回任何响应，请检查网络连接和API配置')
+
+        query.session.using_conversation.uuid = chunk['conversation_id']
+
+    async def _workflow_messages_chunk(self, query: core_entities.Query) -> typing.AsyncGenerator[llm_entities.Message, None]:

Return type annotation is incorrect. This method should return `typing.AsyncGenerator[llm_entities.MessageChunk, None]` to match the actual yielded type and method name suffix `_chunk`.

    async def _workflow_messages_chunk(self, query: core_entities.Query) -> typing.AsyncGenerator[llm_entities.MessageChunk, None]:

issue.body:
## Summary Closes: - https://github.com/elastic/kibana/issues/222388 ## Prompt
Show prompt used **Motivation** This task aims to refine the appearance of alert and event nodes, handle data overflow gracefully using ellipsis and counters. Additionally, we will show tooltips for alert rule names to help users understand alert context at a glance. **Definition of done** - [ ] Update visual appearance of alert label nodes, with `euiTheme.colors.danger` for background-color and `euiTheme.colors.backgroundBasePlain` for text color (based on provided screenshots) - [ ] Update visual appearance of event label, with a `euiTheme.colors. backgroundBasePrimary` background-color and a `euiTheme.colors.textPrimary` for text color (based on provided screenshots) - [ ] If the Label node is: - A single alert: Render a white squared badge with rounded corners that contains a red "warningFilled" icon - A group of events: Render a white squared badge with rounded corners that contains only a "+X" counter - A group of alerts: Render the same triangle for single alerts, but adding a "+X" counter. - A group of events and alerts: Render both badges used in Label nodes that represent groups of events and groups of alerts, in this order. - A single event: Don't render any badge. - [ ] Reuse the `` component introduced in https://github.com/elastic/kibana/pull/228403 to render 1 IP address and a "+X" counter when more than IP is present, and also reveals a tooltip that lists all IPs present - [ ] Reuse the `` component introduced in https://github.com/elastic/kibana/pull/228403 to render 2 flags and a "+X" counter when more than two are present, and also reveals a tooltip that lists all IPs present - [ ] Show a tooltip over label nodes containing the related events or alerts. The tooltip must have a "Performed action" title and list all events and alerts included in the label node. The tooltip must group events and alerts by the frequency they're repeated and render the corresponding red-background or white-background badge when the frequency is greater than 99 repetitions (based on provided screenshots). - [ ] Add `useEuiShadow('m')` style when label nodes are dragging
## Changes ### Visual Styling - **Shape**: Use `backgroundBasePrimary` or `danger` background based on `documentsData` prop - **Shape on hover**: Use `danger` with only alerts, otherwise always `primary` color - **Expand button**: Always use `primary` color. Partially overlap shape - **Shadow**: Added shadow when nodes are being dragged ### Badges Label nodes now display badges based on their content: - **Single event**: No badge - **Single alert**: White squared badge with red warning icon - **Group of events**: White squared badge with "+X" counter - **Group of alerts**: White squared badge with red warning icon and "+X" counter - **Mixed group: one each**: Both badges - Events: White squared badge with "+X" counter - Alerts: Red squared badge with white warning icon - **Mixed group: multiple each**: Both badges - Events: White squared badge with "+X" counter - Alerts: Red squared badge with white warning icon and counter Both badges will display "+99" counters when over the 99 limit. ### Tooltips Only visible when node's label is truncated or number of events/alerts is > limit. Renders: - **Single event**: "Default events" - **Single alert**: "Alerted events" and white squared badge with red warning icon - **Group of events**: "Default events" and White squared badge with "+X" counter - **Group of alerts**: "Alerted events" and red squared badge with white warning icon and "+X" counter - **Mixed group: one each**: Both badges Both badges display the exact amounts. ### Additional data Reused components: - ``: Displays IP addresses with tooltips and counters - ``: Displays country flags with localized names and counters These components were introduced in the previous PR: - https://github.com/elastic/kibana/pull/228403 ### Graph layout Fixed bug in graph layout calculation affecting stacks with an odd number of label nodes (i.e. 3, 5, 7...). They now align the middle node matching the outer stack's edges. See below: | Before | After | |--------|--------| | | | Also made room for details below each label node:
Label nodes with details
### Stories Added 2 stories grouped under a new "Label Node" group: - `label_node.stories.tsx` with controls to play - `label_node_badges.stories.tsx` with all possible use cases related to badges - `label_node_details.stories.tsx` rendering `` and `` ## More details ### Checklist - [x] Any text added follows [EUI's writing guidelines](https://elastic.github.io/eui/#/guidelines/writing), uses sentence case text and includes [i18n support](https://github.com/elastic/kibana/blob/main/src/platform/packages/shared/kbn-i18n/README.md) - [ ] [Documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/kibana/master/development-documentation.html) was added for features that require explanation or tutorials - [x] [Unit or functional tests](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/kibana/master/development-tests.html) were updated or added to match the most common scenarios - [ ] If a plugin configuration key changed, check if it needs to be allowlisted in the cloud and added to the [docker list](https://github.com/elastic/kibana/blob/main/src/dev/build/tasks/os_packages/docker_generator/resources/base/bin/kibana-docker) - [x] This was checked for breaking HTTP API changes, and any breaking changes have been approved by the breaking-change committee. The `release_note:breaking` label should be applied in these situations. - [ ] [Flaky Test Runner](https://ci-stats.kibana.dev/trigger_flaky_test_runner/1) was used on any tests changed - [x] The PR description includes the appropriate Release Notes section, and the correct `release_note:*` label is applied per the [guidelines](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/kibana/master/contributing.html#kibana-release-notes-process) - [x] Review the [backport guidelines](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VyN5k91e5OVumlc0Gb9RPa3h1ewuPE705nRtioPiTvY/edit?usp=sharing) and apply applicable `backport:*` labels. ### Identify risks No risks.

pull_request.title: anki: 25.02.5 -> 25.07.2
pull_request.body:
This includes needing to migrate to a 'uv' based packaging system, since
that's what upstream did.

Unfortunately, `uv sync` as a FoD doesn't work since it's not a stable
output format.

I handled it by writing a hacky "uv.lock to nix" converter (in the form
of the 'update.sh' script), and then using fetchurl to download every
file referenced in the uv.lock.

Using that, combined with the "UV_FIND_LINKS" environment variable lets
uv operate offline, so it seems like that's a good enough solution
there, phew!

The next hurdle was that anki wants us to populate 'pyenv' for an
offline build, and I wasn't sure the exact right 'uv' commands for that.
I ended up with a mix of 'uv export' to make requirements.txt files, and
'uv pip install' to install em. That seems to work okay for most things.

The final problem was that using anki's suggested version of PyQt hits
linker errors. To me, the easiest solution seemed like just using the
already-packaged pyqt packages from nixpkgs, so I did that.

Overall, this feels pragmatic and like it works.

I think the most compelling alternative would be to generate
"requirements.txt" using uv export, relax all the version requirements,
and use nixpkgs-packaged dependencies only.
I ended up not taking that route because not all of anki's dependencies
are present in nixpkgs, and so doing it like done in this PR seemed more
expedient.

That's the notes I have, hopefully this approach seems overall
reasonable!

Fixes #422471

review.body:
## Pull Request Overview This PR implements streaming output functionality for the LangBot system. The core purpose is to enable real-time streaming of AI responses across multiple platform adapters, allowing users to see AI-generated content as it's being produced rather than waiting for the complete response. - Adds streaming output support across multiple platform adapters (Telegram, Lark, DingTalk, WebChat) - Implements streaming message handling for various LLM providers and runners - Introduces a "remove-think" configuration option to filter out reasoning content from AI responses ### Reviewed Changes Copilot reviewed 45 out of 45 changed files in this pull request and generated 8 comments.
Show a summary per file | File | Description | | ---- | ----------- | | web/src/i18n/locales/*.ts | Added internationalization strings for streaming functionality | | web/src/app/infra/http/HttpClient.ts | Implemented streaming HTTP client for web chat interface | | web/src/app/home/pipelines/components/debug-dialog/DebugDialog.tsx | Added streaming toggle and real-time message display | | pkg/provider/runners/*.py | Added streaming support for LocalAgent, Dify, and Dashscope runners | | pkg/provider/modelmgr/requesters/*.py | Implemented streaming methods for various LLM API clients | | pkg/platform/sources/*.py | Added streaming message chunk handling for platform adapters | | pkg/pipeline/respback/respback.py | Added streaming response handling in pipeline | | templates/*.yaml | Added remove-think configuration option |

commits.message: ✅ Actualización automática del precio del dólar

issue.title: Generate GitHub Copilot instructions for Azure PowerShell repository
issue.body:
This PR adds comprehensive GitHub Copilot instructions to help developers work effectively in the Azure PowerShell repository. The instructions provide detailed guidance for building, testing, and developing in this complex codebase containing 200+ PowerShell modules.

## Key Features

### Build System Guidance
- Complete MSBuild command reference with exact timing expectations
- **Critical timing documentation**: Full builds take 45-60 minutes, single modules 15-30 minutes
- **"NEVER CANCEL" warnings** with specific timeout values to prevent premature build termination
- Network connectivity requirements for Azure DevOps package feeds

### Prerequisites and Setup
- Exact installation commands for .NET SDK 8+, PowerShell 7+, platyPS, PSScriptAnalyzer
- Environment setup requirements and execution policy configuration
- Troubleshooting for common setup issues

### Manual Validation Scenarios
The instructions emphasize that building alone is insufficient - developers must manually test functionality:

```powershell
# Import the built module
Import-Module ./artifacts/Debug/Az.YourModule/Az.YourModule.psd1

# Verify cmdlets work correctly
Get-Command -Module Az.YourModule
Get-Help Your-AzCmdlet -Examples

# Test real scenarios with error handling
Your-AzCmdlet -ResourceGroupName "test-rg"
```

### Repository Structure Explanation
- Distinction between SDK-based modules (`/src/`) and AutoRest-generated modules (`/generated/`)
- Development workflows for both module types
- Key directories and their purposes

### Comprehensive Troubleshooting
- Network connectivity issues with specific domain requirements
- Build artifact problems and solutions
- PowerShell module import troubleshooting
- Common error patterns and workarounds

## Timing Expectations

| Command | Expected Time | Timeout Setting |
|---------|---------------|-----------------|
| Full repository build | 45-60 minutes | 90 minutes |
| Single module build | 15-30 minutes | 45 minutes |
| Help generation | 10-15 minutes | 30 minutes |
| Static analysis | 10-15 minutes | 30 minutes |

The instructions begin with a firm directive to follow these guidelines first before searching for additional context, ensuring Copilot prioritizes the documented workflows over generic approaches.

Fixes #28401.

commits.message:
chore(infra): push relay binary to gcp (#10196)

The COS images we currently use to run our Relays ship with an older
Linux kernel that doesn't have some of the nice verifier improvements
for our eBPF relay.

To fix this, we need to use Ubuntu 24.04. To keep things simple there,
we would like to avoid installing Docker on that image and instead run
the Relay raw. To support that, we first need to push the built relay
binary to our staging cloud storage bucket.

Related: #10177
Related: https://github.com/firezone/infra/pull/116

---------

Signed-off-by: Jamil <jamilbk@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: Copilot <175728472+Copilot@users.noreply.github.com>

fix(ci): use correct relay binary location (#10198)

Fixes an issue introduced in #10196.

Related: #10196

fix(ci): compute sha256sum of binaries earlier (#10199)

Fixes an issue where the sha256sum.txt of the relay was not available.

Related: #10198

Add progress-focused training configuration and implement progress detection

- Introduced a new configuration file for progress-focused training in Pokemon Red, enhancing exploration with learned progress detection.
- Implemented a ProgressDetector class to identify meaningful state transitions and compute progress-based rewards.
- Updated the environment to integrate the progress detector, allowing for dynamic reward computation based on state transitions.
- Modified the archive logic to incorporate progress-aware scoring for frontier sampling.
- Added a new training script specifically for progress-focused training mode, demonstrating the use of the new features.

review.body:
## Pull Request Overview This PR implements streaming output functionality for the LangBot system. The core purpose is to enable real-time streaming of AI responses across multiple platform adapters, allowing users to see AI-generated content as it's being produced rather than waiting for the complete response. - Adds streaming output support across multiple platform adapters (Telegram, Lark, DingTalk, WebChat) - Implements streaming message handling for various LLM providers and runners - Introduces a "remove-think" configuration option to filter out reasoning content from AI responses ### Reviewed Changes Copilot reviewed 45 out of 45 changed files in this pull request and generated 8 comments.
Show a summary per file | File | Description | | ---- | ----------- | | web/src/i18n/locales/*.ts | Added internationalization strings for streaming functionality | | web/src/app/infra/http/HttpClient.ts | Implemented streaming HTTP client for web chat interface | | web/src/app/home/pipelines/components/debug-dialog/DebugDialog.tsx | Added streaming toggle and real-time message display | | pkg/provider/runners/*.py | Added streaming support for LocalAgent, Dify, and Dashscope runners | | pkg/provider/modelmgr/requesters/*.py | Implemented streaming methods for various LLM API clients | | pkg/platform/sources/*.py | Added streaming message chunk handling for platform adapters | | pkg/pipeline/respback/respback.py | Added streaming response handling in pipeline | | templates/*.yaml | Added remove-think configuration option |

pull_request.body:
Bumps [commons-net:commons-net](https://github.com/apache/commons-net) from 3.11.1 to 3.12.0.
Changelog

Sourced from commons-net:commons-net's changelog.

Apache Commons Net 3.12.0 Release Notes

The Apache Commons Net team is pleased to announce the release of Apache Commons Net 3.12.0.

Apache Commons Net library contains a collection of network utilities and protocol implementations. Supported protocols include Echo, Finger, FTP, NNTP, NTP, POP3(S), SMTP(S), Telnet, and Whois.

This is a feature and maintenance release. Java 8 or later is required.

For complete information on Apache Commons Net, including instructions on how to submit bug reports, patches, or suggestions for improvement, see the Apache Commons Net website:

https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-net/

Download page: https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-net/download_net.cgi

New features

o Add org.apache.commons.net.nntp.Article#getChild(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add org.apache.commons.net.nntp.Article#getNext(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add private SubnetAddressStringIterable and private SubnetAddressStringIterator to implement SubnetInfo.iterableAddressStrings() and SubnetInfo.streamAddressStrings() #298. Thanks to Lixiongyou, Gary Gregory. o Add SubnetInfo.iterableAddressStrings(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add SubnetInfo.streamAddressStrings(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add FTPCmd.OPTS. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add FTP.opts(String, String). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add FTP.opts(String...). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add FTP.setControlEncoding(Charset). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add --OPTS to FTPClientExample. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o NET-727: Add accessing options map for TFTP request packet and allow using 'blksize' option #331. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add org.apache.commons.net.util.ListenerList.isEmpty(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add org.apache.commons.net.ftp.FTPClient.getSystemTypeOverride(). Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add generics to ListenerList. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Add module-info.class in the JAR file instead of an Automatic-Module-Name in MANIFEST.MF. Thanks to Gary Gregory.

Fixed Bugs

o Increase message limit in IMAPReply.TAGGED_RESPONSE from 80 to 500 characters. Thanks to Andreas Lemke, Gary Gregory. o Increase message limit in IMAPReply.UNTAGGED_RESPONSE from 160 to 500 characters. Thanks to Andreas Lemke, Gary Gregory. o Remove InvalidKeySpecException from AuthenticatingIMAPClient.auth(AUTH_METHOD, String, String) never throws, it's not thrown. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Remove InvalidKeySpecException from org.apache.commons.net.smtp.AuthenticatingSMTPClient.auth(AUTH_METHOD, String, String) never throws, it's not thrown. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Fix SpotBugs RCN_REDUNDANT_NULLCHECK_OF_NONNULL_VALUE in SSLSocketUtils. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Fix PMD UnnecessaryFullyQualifiedName. Thanks to Gary Gregory. o Fix PMD UnusedFormalParameter. Thanks to Gary Gregory.

pull_request.title:
[WIP] I want to change the way the game handles the docked playable area at the bottom.  Note that WindowManager uses SDL3 for window placement and "always on top" behavior, instead of the standard windows API because SDL3 has its own way of handling this.

...
pull_request.body:
Thanks for asking me to work on this. I will get started on it and keep this PR's description up to date as I form a plan and make progress.

Original description:

> I want to change the way the game handles the docked playable area at the bottom.  Note that WindowManager uses SDL3 for window placement and "always on top" behavior, instead of the standard windows API because SDL3 has its own way of handling this.
> 
> Currently the game runs at a 1920x360 resolution and sits at the bottom.  Instead I want to to run at 1920x1080 resolution, but only the bottom 1920x360 area is clickable.  Anything above that bottom area should have "click-through" behavior.  This can be done using SDL3 HitTest.  There should be a separate helper class for this, or it can be added to WindowManager if that makes more sense.  We should be able to enable/disable click-through in rectangular regions so that eventually menu pop-ups can happen anywhere on the screen that are clickable, and they are made temporarily clickable.  Then when we are done with the pop up, it can go away and that area is click-through again.  Another use for this would be another 1920x1080 "replay strip" that sits above the normal strip, where the player can replay the failed session of a previous hero...and that becomes temporarily clickable and not click-through.
> 
> In GameConfig, the concept of VirtualWidth/VirtualHeight and InternalWorldWidth/InternalWorldHeight needs to be modified.  It should represent the fact that the actual resolution is 1920x1080...but the initial playable area is just the 1920x360 at the bottom.  Update these variables and the corresponding code to reflect this in the best way possible.  Update any wording in copilot-instructions that references the game resolution.
> 
> Pay attention to the Build Requirements in the copilot-instructions when building this.
